skill.name: fiftyone-pr-triage
skill.description: Triage FiftyOne GitHub issues by validating status, categorizing resolution, and generating standardized responses. Use when reviewing issues to determine if fixed, won't fix, not reproducible, no longer relevant, or still valid.
skill.summary: Triage FiftyOne GitHub issues by validating status, categorizing resolution, and generating standard...
skill.author: AdonaiVera

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and response templates for GitHub issue triage. All detected patterns are false positives from markdown code examples. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or environment variable reads exist. The skill is pure instructional content.

content.value_statement: GitHub issue triage requires consistent categorization and clear communication. This skill provides a structured workflow with decision trees and response templates for FiftyOne repository maintainers.
actual_capabilities: Categorize issues into five triage states based on investigation
Provide structured workflows for searching codebase and git history
Generate standardized response templates for each triage category
Guide maintainers through systematic decision trees
Document code references with file paths and line numbers
Include commands for GitHub CLI and git operations
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI and git to be installed and configured
Designed specifically for FiftyOne repository structure
Does not automatically execute commands or close issues
Cannot reproduce bugs without proper development environment

use_cases.title: Maintain healthy issue tracker
use_cases.description: Keep issue backlog organized by systematically categorizing and responding to bug reports and feature requests.

use_cases.title: Provide consistent user communication
use_cases.description: Use standardized response templates to ensure users receive clear explanations for issue resolutions.

use_cases.title: Assist with issue management
use_cases.description: Help maintainers by following documented workflows to identify duplicates and verify bug reports.

prompt_templates.title: Initial issue triage
prompt_templates.prompt: Triage this FiftyOne issue. Read the full description, search the codebase for related code, check git history for recent fixes, and categorize as already fixed, won't fix, not reproducible, no longer relevant, or still valid.

prompt_templates.title: Bug verification
prompt_templates.scenario: Verify if bug can be reproduced
prompt_templates.prompt: Use fiftyone-pr-triage skill to verify this bug report. Search for related code modules, check recent commits, and determine if the issue is reproducible or already fixed.

prompt_templates.title: Duplicate detection
prompt_templates.prompt: Search closed issues and merged PRs using the fiftyone-pr-triage workflow. Identify if this is a duplicate and generate a response linking to the original issue.

prompt_templates.title: Feature request evaluation
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply the fiftyone-pr-triage decision tree to evaluate this feature request. Determine if it aligns with project scope and generate an appropriate response with clear reasoning.

output_examples.input: Triage this issue: User reports dataset loading fails with memory error on large datasets using FiftyOne v0.21
output: Search results: Found load_dataset in fiftyone/core/dataset.py line 456
Git history: No recent fixes for memory issues in dataset loading
Next steps: Request minimal reproducible example and dataset size details

output_examples.input: Check if this feature request about adding export to CSV is already implemented
output: Codebase search: Found export_csv method in fiftyone/utils/export.py line 123
Git log: PR #3456 merged 3 months ago implementing CSV export
Response: Point user to documentation and suggest upgrading to latest version

output_examples.input: Investigate if this old issue from 2022 about Python 3.7 compatibility is still relevant
output: Current requirements: Python 3.8 minimum per setup.py line 45
Reasoning: FiftyOne dropped Python 3.7 support in v0.18, issue is outdated

best_practices: Always check git history and closed issues before marking an issue as new
Provide specific commit hashes or PR numbers when referencing fixes
Request minimal reproducible examples when issues cannot be verified
anti_patterns: Closing issues without searching for duplicates or related fixes
Using vague explanations that do not reference specific code locations
Skipping the investigation checklist before categorizing issues

faq.question: Does this skill work with repositories other than FiftyOne?
faq.answer: The workflow is designed for FiftyOne but the triage categories and decision trees can be adapted to other projects.

faq.question: Will this skill automatically close GitHub issues?
faq.answer: No. It generates response templates and recommendations but requires human review before posting responses or closing issues.

faq.question: What tools are required to use this skill effectively?
faq.answer: You need GitHub CLI, git, access to the repository, and the ability to run grep and find commands.

faq.question: How does this skill handle security vulnerabilities?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on general issue triage. Security issues should follow separate responsible disclosure procedures.

faq.question: Can I customize the response templates?
faq.answer: Yes. The templates provide a starting structure that you can modify based on specific context and project communication style.

faq.question: What should I do if an issue fits multiple categories?
faq.answer: Follow the decision tree in priority order. For example, if an issue is both fixed and outdated, categorize as already fixed.
